import React from 'react' import Sidebar from '../../components/sidebar/Sidebar' import Navsection from '../../components/navbar/Navsection' import './chapter3.scss' import { useNavigate } from "react-router-dom" const Chapter3 = () => { // ---------------- const navigate = useNavigate(); const transfer = (txt) => { if (txt.includes(":)")) { setTimeout(() => navigate('/'), 500); } } const submit = (e) => { e.preventDefault(); const code = document.getElementById("input").value; const data = { code: code }; fetch('/code3', { method: 'POST', headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' }, body: JSON.stringify(data) }) .then(res => res.text()) .then(txt => alert(txt)) .then(txt => transfer(txt)) } return (

Chapter 3: Java Methods

A method is a block of code which only runs when it is invoked. We can pass data (known as parameters) into a method. Methods are called to perform things, so we also called method as functions. It is much easier to define a method once and reuse it many times.

Java has some build-in methods like System.out.println(), However, we can make our own methods. Note, a method must be declared within a class.

aMethod () is the name. static means that this method belong to the Main class, and it is not a object of the Main class. void means that this method returns nothing.

Call a Method

For example: Inside Main, call the aMethod() method:

public class Main {'{'}
static void aMethod() {'{'} System.out.println("A Java Tutor!");{'}'}
public static void main(String[] args) {'{'}
myMethod(); {'}'}
{'}'}
